State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taoyuan South Road Taiyuan 030001 China Herein, a simple preparation strategy was developed to enhance the oxygen replenishment capacity of CuMn2O4 catalysts by synergically engineering the Cu+ and oxygen vacancies (VO). The surface physicochemical properties of the CuMn2O4 catalysts were regulated by the annealing temperature and solvent, and the effect of two different VO (VO from Cu+-VO−Mn3+ and Mn2+-VO−Mn3+ were denoted as VO(CM) and VO(MM), respectively) on oxygen activation were studied. The results demonstrated that the Cu+ and VO synergically promoted the low-temperature reducibility, adsorbed oxygen species, and the oxygen replenishment of CuMn2O4 catalysts. Especially, the abundant Cu+ cations and VO(CM) greatly promoted the transformation of O2 → O2 − → O−. The prepared CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance (T90 = 208 °C), and the reaction route of toluene oxidation over CuMn2O4-EG-350 was confirmed as follows: toluene-benzyl alcohol-benzoate-maleic anhydride-CO2 and H2O. The Cu+-rich CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalyst with an efficient synthetic strategy is a promising industrial catalyst for toluene elimination. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Toluene oxidation CuMn2O4 Cu+-rich Oxygen activation 1 Introduction The emission of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is the major class of air pollution and have drawn extensive attention worldwide. The VOC emission results in serious environmental concerns such as carcinogenicity, offensive odor, headache, petrochemical smog, and ozone formation [1–4]. As a typical aromatic compound, toluene is widely used for production in several industries, including processing industries, chemical industries, and petrochemical industries, and it has been used as a model compound for the research on VOC removal [5]. Numerous treatment techniques, such as photocatalysis, adsorption, ozonation, catalytic combustion, and biological degradation, have been applied to eliminate toluene [6–8]. Catalytic combustion strategy stands out among these technologies owing to its high efficiency and eco-friendly value [9,10]. A technical bottleneck in toluene oxidation technology is to design catalysts with high catalytic activity. Although noble metals, such as Pd, Au, Pt, and Ag, exhibit excellent activities for toluene removal, their disadvantages of low availability, high cost, and low sintering resistance limit their widespread application [11–14]. Hence, more and more researchers pay their attention to transitional oxides on account of the advantages of lower cost, higher thermal stability, and better poisoning resistance [15–18]. Bimetallic Cu–Mn oxides have been successfully used for the oxidation VOCs under relatively low temperatures, owing to their distinctive physicochemical properties, tremendous potential, and strong synergistic interaction [19–21]. However, it is still a challenge to maximize the potential advantages of Cu–Mn oxides catalysts. Oxygen vacancy engineering is considered a positive strategy for enhancing the catalytic performance of catalysts [22], which is closely related to the reactant adsorption and oxygen replenishment [23]. Li et al. [24] synthesized a series of defect enhanced Co-Mn binary oxides by a self-redox method, and the defect engineering promoted the low-temperature reducibility, oxygen adsorption capacity, and lattice oxygen mobility efficiency of the spinel Co-Mn catalysts. Wang et al. [23] reported that the types of oxygen vacancy in Fe doped MnO2 catalysts worked different on catalyst activity, and the VO (FM) (the oxygen vacancy from Fe3+-VO(FM)-Mn3+ was denoted as VO (FM)) promoted the toluene oxidation. The oxygen vacancy content is affected by the preparation method, precursor, annealing temperature, metal doping and other factors in the preparation process of catalysts [25–28]. Dong et al. [22] prepared a series of MnO2 with different oxygen vacancy concentration by doping Cu2+, and Xu et al. [29] obtained CM catalysts with abundant vacancy by urea solid reaction treatment. Wei et al. [30] investigated the effect of the annealing temperature on the oxygen species of the CuO-MnOx catalyst, and it was found that the oxygen vacancy of Cu-Mn was altered. Li et al. [31] developed a facile method for Mn-Cu bimetallic oxide preparation and found that the presence of Cu+ was important for oxygen adsorption. Our previous research confirmed that the existence of Cu+ and Cu2+ in the AMn2O4 spinel improved the ability to activate oxygen of CuMn2O4 prepared by the hard template method [32]. However, relatively rarely researches on the synergically engineering of oxygen vacancy and Cu+ for enhancing toluene catalytic oxidation were reported. In this work, a facile template-free method was successfully developed to fabricate mesoporous CuMn2O4 spinel catalysts with abundant Cu+ and oxygen vacancy. The influences of the solvent and annealing temperature were investigated for the structure-property relationships of the oxygen adsorption, activation, and migration capacity on the catalysts. The results of XPS, O2-TPD, and H2-TPR demonstrated that the oxygen adsorption, activation, and migration ability of the catalysts can be greatly improved by the abundant Cu+ and oxygen vacancies, and the catalyst prepared in mixed alcohol solution (ethanol and glycol) with annealing temperature of 350 °C (CuMn2O4-EG-350) behaved the best catalytic performance. Furthermore, the main intermediate products were identified, and the reaction mechanism of toluene oxidation over CuMn2O4-EG-350 was clarified by the in-situ DRIFTS. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of CuMn2O4-EG Manganous acetate (0.02 mol) and copper acetate (0.01 mol) were added to 200 mL of a mixed alcohol solution (ethanol: glycol = 3:1) under magnetic stirring at 25 °C to form an acetate solution. Afterward, oxalic acid (0.036 mol) was added to another 50 ml of a mixed alcohol solution (ethanol: glycol = 3:1). The oxalic acid solution was quickly added to the metal acetate solution under vigorous stirring for 0.5 h at room temperature. Then, the precipitate was collected through centrifugation and then dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, the obtained precipitate was calcined at the corresponding temperature for 2 h under air atmosphere to gain the homogeneous mesoporous CuMn2O4 catalysts. The CuMn2O4 catalysts fabricated with the annealing temperature of 350, 400, and 450 °C were labeled as CuMn2O4-EG-350, CuMn2O4-EG-400 and CuMn2O4-EG-450, respectively. CuMn2O4 were also prepared under ethanol and water with different annealing temperature. CuMn2O4-E-350, CuMn2O4-E-400, and CuMn2O4-E-450 samples were synthesized with the same steps, except that the solvent was ethanol. CuMn2O4-W-350 was obtained with the same steps in an aqueous solution. 2.2 Characterization The properties of the prepared CuMn2O4 catalysts were detected by utilizing techniques, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TG), N2 adsorption-desorption (BET), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman, oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), and in-situ DRIFT experiment. The detailed methods were displayed in the supporting information. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement The activity of the samples for toluene oxidation was evaluated using a fixed-bed reactor, with the feeding gasses controlled by mass flow controllers. The inlet simulated gas containing 1000 ppm toluene was generated in a thermostatic water bath and mixed with 20% O2. The flowing reactant gas stream was introduced through 0.2 g sample with a flow rate of 66.7 mL min−1, giving a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 20,000 mL g−1 h−1, and the activity of the samples was evaluated under a temperature range of 150 °C–270 °C. The toluene concentrations were detected online with a gas chromatograph (GC-2014, Shimadzu), and the CO2 concentrations were monitored using a portable Fourier-transform infrared gas analyzer (Gasmet Instruments DX-4000). The toluene conversion was calculated by the equation: η = C in − C out C in × 100 % where η is the toluene conversion rate, and Cin and Cout represent the inlet and outlet toluene concentrations, respectively. 3 Results 3.1 Structural and morphological analysis The pyrolysis of the precursor has a strong influence on the texture and crystalline phase of the products [33]. Meso-structured CuMn2O4 catalysts were obtained through controlled thermal decomposition of oxalate precursor. Thus, the TG-DTG analysis was conducted to simulate the thermal stability behavior of the prepared CuMn2O4 catalysts (Fig. S1). After the annealing, the oxalate precursors lost about 60% of its original weight, and the two precursors had similar thermal decomposition curves. The slight weight loss before 190 °C belonged to the coordinated water, and the two dramatically decreasing weight loss at 190–230 °C and 240–290 °C were corresponded to the pyrolysis of copper oxalate and manganese oxalate, respectively. The residual weight of CuMn2O4-EG precursor became constant when the temperature rose to 300 °C as depicted in Fig. S1(a), however, the weight of CuMn2O4-E (Fig. S1(b)) continued to decline slowly. Based on the DTG results, the decomposition of CuMn2O4-EG precursor was faster than that of CuMn2O4-E precursor, indicating the thermal stability of CuMn2O4-E precursor was higher. After the decomposition, the weight of CuMn2O4-EG first rose and then fell, and this phenomenon was caused by the oxidation low-priced metals at first, and then, the release of lattice oxygen led to the drop of the weight as the increasing temperature. However, because of the good thermal stability the CuMn2O4-E precursor, the slow release of CO2 resulted in the continuous weight loss. The wide-angle XRD patterns were carried out to determine the crystalline phases of CuMn2O4 samples as described in Fig. 1 . The XRD patterns of the CuMn2O4 catalysts featured peaks at 2θ = 18.6°, 30.5°, 36.0°, 57.8°, and 63.6°, which correspond to (1 1 1), (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (5 1 1), and (4 4 0) crystal planes of the standard spinel structure (JCPDS NO. 35–1171). This indicated that the oxalate decomposed and converted to the spinel through complete phase transformation. The crystal phase of CuO (PDF-#48–1548) was detected in CuMn2O4-W-350 sample, indicating pure phase CuMn2O4 cannot be obtained in aqueous solution. No phases of other substances were detected in the CuMn2O4 samples except for CuMn2O4-W-350, implying that all the samples fabricated in alcohol solution were pure phase spinel materials. Besides, it can be observed that CuMn2O4-EG-350 and CuMn2O4-E-350 presented no evident peaks except for the slight peak at 36°, implying the low crystallinity. Obviously, the peaks of the CuMn2O4-EG-T became sharp and strong with the increasing annealing temperature, implying the enlargement of crystallinity and particle size. The same result can be obtained for the CuMn2O4-E-T catalysts as displayed in Fig. S1. Generally, the low crystallinity may lead to more oxygen vacancy, which was conducive to the toluene oxidation. The texture properties of the CuMn2O4 were further analyzed by the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 2 ). Apparently, all the catalysts exhibited hysteresis loops of typical Langmuir IV isotherms, indicating the presence of mesoporous [34]. The electrostatic interaction between the colloidal particles hindered the growth of the crystal grains by using the alcohol sol-gel method, which was conducive to the generation of mesoporous structure. Besides, the release of CO2 and CO gas during the pyrolysis of Cu-Mn oxalate further created abundant mesoporous and oxygen vacancy. The presence of mesoporous was confirmed by the distribution measurements as depicted in Fig. 2(b), and the textural parameters of the specific surface area, average pore width, and pore volume were shown in Table 1 . Visibly, the increasing annealing temperature decreased the specific surface area of CuMn2O4 catalysts due to the collapse and combination of the pore network under high temperature. The specific area of CuMn2O4-EG-350 was 231.6 m2/g, while that of the CuMn2O4-EG-450 dramatically decreased to 102.4 m2/g. The specific surface area of CuMn2O4-EG-400 maintained 208.4 m2/g, but that of the CuMn2O4-E-400 sample was only 136.3 m2/g, indicating the pore structure stability of CuMn2O4-EG was higher than CuMn2O4-E, which was consistent with the TG results. Furthermore, the abundant mesoporous and large specific area provided more surface exposed oxygen vacancies and good diffusion conditions for toluene oxidation [35]. The microscopic analysis was performed by using SEM to investigate the influence of solvent and annealing temperature over CuMn2O4 catalysts as shown in Fig. 3 . Before annealing, the precursors of CuMn2O4-EG and CuMn2O4-E behaved a smooth surface with no specific morphology structure. The morphology of the CuMn2O4-EG-350 and CuMn2O4-E-350 catalysts became rough and exhibited a formless particle accumulation, along with that some fragments and broad cracks can be found after thermal treatment. It can be inferred that the decomposition of oxalate had a huge impact on the structure of the material, and no significant difference was observed among the SEM images of CuMn2O4-EG-T catalysts as shown in Fig. S2. Two different structured particles were found in the CuMn2O4-W catalyst as shown in Figs. 3(c) and 4 (f), and it was in good agreement with the XRD results, implying that pure CuMn2O4 spinel was not obtained in an aqueous solution. The crystalline structures of the CuMn2O4-EG-350 sample were further characterized by TEM as depicted in Fig. 4. Fig. 4(a) showed that the CuMn2O4-EG-350 had a loose and porous structure, and it was structured by uniform nanoparticles with a size of 6–8 nm. Such nano grains will expose more active sites and oxygen vacancies, and the porous structure was beneficial to the adsorption of toluene and oxygen molecules. Meanwhile, large numbers of lattice fringes in the CuMn2O4-EG-350 were observed as shown in Fig. 4(b). The spacing distances of the lattice fringes were 4.80 Å, 2.94 Å, and 2.47 Å, which can be attributed to the d values of the Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 (1 1 1), (2 2 0), and (3 1 1) planes. These results indicated the exposure of oxygen vacancies and the possibility to increase the specific surface area of the catalysts. 3.2 Chemical states and redox behavior The oxidation states of surface Cu, Mn, and O on the synthesized CuMn2O4 spinel catalysts were evaluated by using XPS measurements. The asymmetrical Cu 2p3/2 spectra were shown in Fig. 5 (a), and the peaks at around 930–932 eV belonged to Cu+ species, while the peaks at 933–936 eV were assigned to Cu2+ species [36,37]. As calculated in Table 2 , the molar ratio of Cu+/Cun+ decreased markedly with the augment of annealing temperature, and the surface Cu+/Cun+ ratios of on CuMn2O4-EG-350, CuMn2O4-EG-400, CuMn2O4-EG-450 surface were 46.8%, 26.5%, and 15.3%, respectively. The results verified that the annealing temperature had an unparalleled effect to the surface Cu valence distribution, and the redox couple Cu+ + Mn4+ ↔ Cu2+ + Mn3+ moved to the right with the increasing temperature [29]. According to the principle of electrostatic balance [22], it meant the existence of numerous oxygen vacancies, and the abundant presence of Cu+ species were stabilized by the interaction between Cu and Mn as Cu2+-O-Mn3+ → Cu+-VO(CM)-Mn3+ (VO(CM) represented the oxygen vacancy between the neighboring Cu+ and Mn3+ions). Besides, the Cu+ concentration of CuMn2O4-E-350 and CuMn2O4-W-350 were much lower than that of the CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalyst, meaning that the solvent can also affect the surface oxidation state of the as-prepared CuMn2O4 spinel materials. The addition of ethylene glycol in the solvent promoted the production of Cu+ and VO(CM). Generally, the presence of abundant oxygen vacancies will facilitate the oxygen activation and oxygen migration. The results proved that the Cu+ concentration and VO(CM) content can be regulated by the annealing temperature and solvent, and the CuMn2O4-E-350 exhibited the highest Cu+ concentration and VO(CM) content. The Mn 2p3/2 XPS spectra were fitted into three components centered at 640.6 eV, 641.9 eV and 644.2 eV, attributed to the surface Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+ species in the CuMn2O4 spinel as illustrated in Fig. 5(b) [36,37]. As calculated in Table 2, though the as-prepared catalysts were treated with different annealing conditions and solvent, no obvious influence on the manganese valence distribution of the catalysts was found. Meanwhile, it had been reported that a higher Mn4+/Mnn+ molar ratio indicated more redox cycles of Mn cations, which was highly associated with the toluene oxidation activity [38]. However, the similar Mn4+ molar ratio implied that the effect of Mn4+content could be ignored in this study. The results confirmed that the plentiful Mn3+ was the dominant state of Mn in CuMn2O4 spinel catalysts, and the presence of Mn2+ and Mn4+ cations will promote the generation of oxygen vacancies according to the charge compensation mechanism. In other words, the existence of the polyvalent Mnn+ in the spinel structure also facilitated the promotion of its adjacent oxygen vacancy concentration (Mn3+-O-Mn3+ → Mn2+-VO(MM)-Mn3+, VO(MM) represented the oxygen vacancy between the neighboring Mn2+ and Mn3+ions), enhancing the oxygen storage capacity and oxygen migration capability. The high-resolution O 1 s spectra of CuMn2O4 were displayed in Fig. S3. The signals at 529.9–530.0 eV and 531.2–531.3 eV could be assigned to the lattice oxygen species (Olat) and the adsorbed oxygen species (Oad), respectively [39]. Visibly, the effect of the annealing temperature and solvent to the binding energy of the lattice oxygen can be ignored, indicating that the catalyst had similar lattice oxygen activity. All the CuMn2O4 spinel catalysts possessed abundant chemically adsorbed oxygen with the Oad/Olat ratios ranging around 0.7–1.03, which was conducive to the replenishment of the consumed oxygen species during the toluene oxidation process. Fig. S4 showed the Raman spectra of as-prepared CuMn2O4 spinel samples. The peaks detected at 550–650 cm−1 can be ascribed to the Mn-O bond of Mn (Ⅲ, Ⅳ) in MnO6 octahedra [40]. No other peaks were observed including that of the Mn-O-Mn bond, because Cu2+-O-Mn3+ entities replaced the Mn2+-O-Mn3+, confirming the strong synergy of Cu and Mn species [32]. As the annealing temperature decreases, the peaks belonging to the Mn-O was much weaker and nearly disappeared, indicating the CuMn2O4-EG-350 possessed the most oxygen vacancy. Therefore, the vacancy emergence-annihilation could be achieved more easily, and the oxygen mobility was enhanced during the reaction. As such, the catalytic activity of toluene oxidation was improved. Generally, the low-temperature reduction behavior represented the lattice oxygen mobility. The H2-TPR profiles of CuMn2O4 were provided in Fig. 6 , and the H2 consumption was listed in Table 3 . Apparently, two discernible hydrogen uptake peaks for all the CuMn2O4 samples were observed, the reduction peaks at low temperature belonged to Cu2+ → Cu0, and the peaks at high temperature were attributed to Mn3+ → Mn2+ [29,32]. As illustrated in Fig. 6(a), the CuMn2O4-EG-350 sample showed the best low-temperature reducible capability with the reduction peaks of Cu2+ → Cu and Mn3+ → Mn2+ at 212 °C and 235 °C. This meant that the presence of Cu+ and VO(CM) promoted the fluidity of lattice oxygen, which was beneficial to the supplement of lattice oxygen, and the catalytic activity of the CuMn2O4-EG-350 was improved. The reductive temperatures of the CuMn2O4-EG samples increased with the exaltation of annealing temperature, due to the higher crystallinity along with the less defects [41]. Moreover, the theoretical H2 consumption of CuMn2O4 was 8.421 mol/g, while the CuMn2O4-EG-350 sample possessed the lowest H2 consumption (7.24 mmol/g). The average oxidation state (AOS) of CuMn2O4-EG-350 was much lower than others, indicating the presence of abundant oxygen vacancies. Although the effect of solvent on the redox ability of the catalyst was not obvious as shown in Fig. 6(b), CuMn2O4-EG-350 still behaved the best low-temperature reduction ability. Combined with the XPS results, it was clear that this phenomenon was caused by the presence of abundant Cu+ cations and oxygen vacancies. Therefore, it can be inferred that the abundant oxygen vacancies and high-density Cu+ cations of the CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalysts were conducive to replenishment of active lattice oxygen. The O2-TPD measurement had been performed to investigate the oxygen adsorption behavior of the catalysts as shown in Fig. 7 . For CuMn2O4, the desorption peaks appearing below 200 °C, 200–400 °C, and above 400 °C were usually attributed to the weakly adsorbed oxygen (O2 −), the chemically adsorbed oxygen species (O−) from oxygen vacancies, and the lattice oxygen species (O2−), respectively. Especially, the desorption peaks at around 200–400 °C was related to the adsorbed oxygen species (O−) on the vacancies, which can be the reflection of the oxygen vacancies of samples. As illustrated in Fig. 7, all the CuMn2O4 spinel catalysts can be divided into four discernible peaks at around 120–160 °C, 210–250 °C, 340–410 °C, and 460–500 °C, attributed to the ordinarily chemically adsorbed O2 −, two kinds of O− species from VO(CM) and VO(MM), and the active lattice oxygen O2−, respectively. The catalysts had similar surface lattice oxygen species desorption temperature (centered at 460–500 °C), indicating that the influence of lattice oxygen activity can be ignored. Due to the low-valent cations (Cu+, Mn2+) and the adjacent vacancies (VO(CM), VO(MM)), the gaseous oxygen was adsorbed, induced to Oδ+-Oδ−, and then dissociated into two kinds of O− according to the following pathways: (1) C u + + V O ( CM ) + O δ + − O δ − → C u 2 + + O 2 − (2) C u + + O 2 − + V O ( CM ) → C u 2 + + 2 O − (3) M n 2 + + V O ( MM ) + O δ + − O δ − → M n 3 + + O 2 − (4) M n 2 + + O 2 − + V O ( MM ) → M n 3 + + 2 O − The intensity of oxygen desorption peaks at 200–300 °C (O− a) drastically decreased, while the peak at 300–400 °C (O− b) had a slightly change with the increasing annealing temperature as depicted in Fig. 7(a). According to the XPS analysis, the Cu+ concentration of CuMn2O4-EG decreased visibly and the manganese valence distribution maintained the same as the increasing annealing temperature, which will lead to corresponding changes of the O− desorption in the adjacent vacancies (VO(CM), VO(MM)). The desorption amount of the O− species adjacent to Cu+ cations (DO-a) was fitted and summarized in Table 3. Visibly, the content of DO-a decreases rapidly as the annealing temperature increases. The result meant that the low-temperature peak belonged to the O− species in VO(CM), and the latter peak was ascribed to the O− species in the VO(MM). Generally, a lower desorption temperature suggested that it was conducive to the generation of the active oxygen species, which meant that Cu+ and VO(CM) synergistically decided the oxygen activation ability of the CuMn2O4 catalysts, and the CuMn2O4-EG-350 sample possessed most surface oxygen vacancies and a powerful ability to activate oxygen. The O2-TPD files of CuMn2O4 samples prepared in different solvents were displayed in Fig. 7(b). Two O− desorption peaks and two surface lattice oxygen desorption peaks (O2−) were observed over the CuMn2O4-W-350, and this phenomenon was caused by the presence of two different phases based on the XRD analysis. 3.3 Catalytic performance The catalytic efficiency of CuMn2O4 catalysts was investigated at 160–270 °C. The temperature dependence of toluene removal rate over the catalysts were illustrated in Fig. 8 (a), and the temperature of mineralization into CO2 was depicted in Fig. S5. The catalytic evaluation criterion was usually measured by T90 (temperature of 90% toluene conversion), and the T90 of different catalysts ranked as follows: CuMn2O4-EG-350 (208 °C) < CuMn2O4-EG-400 (215 °C) < CuMn2O4-E-350 (218 °C) < CuMn2O4-EG-450 (230 °C) < CuMn2O4-W-350 (244 °C). Especially, the yield of the CO2 was consistent with the conversion of toluene when the reaction temperature was higher than T90, and no CO was observed during the activity evaluation process, suggesting the completely degradation into nontoxic product (CO2 and H2O). The CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalyst exhibited a high catalytic activity compared with the related samples reported in the literatures (Table S1), indicating that the toluene oxidation can be promoted by synergistically engineering Cu+ and VO(CM). The oxygen concentration was an important factor in practical application, and Fig. 8(b) depicted the influence of the oxygen concentration over CuMn2O4-EG-350 spinel for toluene oxidation. Obviously, the inlet oxygen concentration had a certain effect for toluene oxidation below 230 °C, and the catalytic activity of CuMn2O4-EG-350 decreased slightly with oxygen concentration decreasing from 20% to 5%. However, when the temperature was above 240 °C, the complete combustion of toluene can be achieved even at an oxygen concentration of 5% (T90 = 228 °C). The above results revealed that the Cu+-rich CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalyst can adapt to low oxygen environment. Fig. S6 presented the effect of different GHSV over the CuMn2O4-EG-350 sample, in order to investigate the adaptability of practical industrial applications. As expected, with the rise of GHSV from 20,000 to 80,000 mL/g/h, the toluene conversion rate on the as-prepared CuMn2O4-EG-350 decreased at the same temperature. This was attributed to that the shorter residence time suppressed the oxidation process, which was not conducive to the rapid reaction of toluene. Nevertheless, the T90 of CuMn2O4-EG-350 still can be achieved at 232 °C under a GHSV of 80,000 mL/g/h. To probe the effect of water vapor over the CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalyst, 2 and 5 vol% H2O steam was added into the reaction system. As shown in Fig. 9 (a), a small amount of water vapor (2 vol%) will not affect the activity, while slightly inhibition of activity was observed in the presence of 5 vol% water. To further investigate the water-resistance of the CuMn2O4-EG-350 spinel catalyst, the on-stream reaction experiment was carried out at 210 °C and 240 °C with 5 vol% water vapors. The toluene conversion dropped apparently when H2O was introduced into the feeding reactant at 210 °C as shown in Fig. 9(b), indicating the inhibitory effect of water on catalytic activity. As H2O was shut down, the catalytic efficiency regained to the initial level, suggesting that the impact of water was completely reversible. The complete conversion was maintained during at 240 °C, it meant that increasing the temperature appropriately can eliminate the interference of water on the reaction. 3.4 In-situ drifts The in-situ DRIFTS experiments were employed to investigate the sophisticated oxidation progress over the CuMn2O4-EG-350. Fig. 10 (a) presented the time-dependent DRIFTS of CuMn2O4-EG-350 with 1000 ppm toluene + 20% O2/N2 at 160 °C. After 5 min, the typical skeletal stretching vibrations of the aromatic ring were identified with the peaks at 1600, 1522, 1490, and 1448 cm−1 [39,42,43]. The weak band at 1472 cm−1 was the asymmetric deformation vibration of the -CH3 group [44,45], symbolizing the adsorption of toluene. The intensity of -CH3 did not increase with extended time, implying the initial oxidation of toluene was rapid. The weak band at 1026 cm−1 was ascribed to the CH in plane bending vibrations of aromatic rings, while the multiple bands belonged to the CO stretching vibration were detected at 1145 and 1180 cm−1, which were characteristic of benzyl alcohol species [46–48]. This meant that the methyl group can be easily transformed into alkoxide species through interaction with the catalyst. The strong bands that appeared at 1540, and 1410 cm−1 can be ascribed to asymmetric and symmetric −COO− stretching vibration, and the bands at 1559, 1506 cm−1 belong to aromatic ring vibration of benzoate species [42,49,50]. Additionally, the separation distance of asymmetric (1540 cm−1) and symmetric (1411) υ(C=O) bands was 129 cm−1, manifesting the carboxylate species were bonded to the Mn valence ions with a bridging bidentate configuration [51]. The bands at 1307 and 1246 cm−1 were characteristic of maleic anhydride [52,53], indicating the aromatic ring can be destroyed at 160 °C. Furthermore, the strong band of carbonate species was observed at 1376 cm−1 [54,55], indicating the further cleavage of maleic anhydride. With time extending, the intensity of carbonate species increased significantly, suggesting the accumulation of surface manganese carbonate and the poisoning of the active sites. This suggested that the toluene oxidation process follows the benzyl alcohol-benzoate-maleic anhydride-CO2 and H2O pathway. Fig. 10(b) displayed the DRIFTS under 240 °C, and it can be observed that there was no significant change in the types of intermediates, indicating that the increasing reaction temperature did not change the reaction path of the catalyst. It was worth noting that although the reaction temperature was increased to 240 °C, the accumulation of carbonate was first noticed, and then the benzoate species increased substantially. This meant that the accumulation of carbonate and benzoate was a key factor in inhibiting catalyst activity over CuMn2O4-EG-350. 3.5 Discussion The catalytic oxidation process of toluene over transition oxides usually followed the Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism [56,57]. Therefore, enhancing the lattice oxygen activity and the supplementary capacity of lattice oxygen were two major ways to improve the catalyst activity. The lattice oxygen activity was affected by the electronegativity of A-site metals in the AMn2O4 (A = Cu, Ni, Zn) spinel catalysts, because of the electronic delocalization effect in Cu2+-O2−-Mn3+ entity [32]. According to the dual-redox mechanism proposed in our previous studies, it was a feasible way to enhance the activation oxygen ability. The surface oxygen vacancies were considered conducive for gas oxygen adsorption, and the physical adsorption of oxygen was usually easy to achieve [58]. In this work, the ratio of Cun+ species and oxygen vacancies were engineered by the pyrolysis temperature and solvent, and the Cu-Mn bimetallic spinel catalysts with abundant Cu+ and vacancies was prepared. The well dispersed Cu+ cations and adjacent vacancies (VO(CM)) acted as oxygen acceptor facilitate, and the oxygen activation capability of the CuMn2O4 was promoted. Besides, the lattice oxygen activity was not significantly affected by the structure or preparation method, indicating the influence of the lattice oxygen activity can be ignored in this study. Since the active lattice oxygen will be consumed continuously during the toluene oxidation process, the replenishment of lattice oxygen played a key role for the improvement of catalytic efficiency. In fact, the oxygen activation was usually considered to be the rate determining step in many oxidation reactions [59]. Excitingly, the prepared CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalyst had an amazing Cu+ density and exhibited excellent ability to activate oxygen, thus the continuously replenished lattice oxygen can attack toluene molecules and oxidizes them into CO2 and H2O. 4 Conclusion In order to enhance the oxygen activation capacity of CuMn2O4 spinel catalyst, a simple preparation strategy was developed to synergically engineer the Cu+ and oxygen vacancies by the solvent and annealing temperature. The characterization results showed that lower annealing temperature and the addition of ethylene glycol were conducive to the generation of Cu+ and oxygen vacancies, and the addition of ethylene glycol was beneficial to improve the thermal stability of CuMn2O4. The O2-TPD results confirmed that the presence of abundant Cu+ and Cu+-VO(CM) greatly promoted the transformation of O2 → O2 − → O−, and the CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance (T90 = 208 °C). The in-situ DRIFTS results showed that the oxidation of toluene on the CuMn2O4-EG-350 spinel followed the toluene-benzyl alcohol-benzoate-maleic anhydride-CO2 and H2O pathway. In general, a facile template-free method was successfully developed to fabricate VO(CM)-rich CuMn2O4 spinel catalysts, and it provides a promising industrial catalyst for toluene removal. coredata.dc:description: Herein, a simple preparation strategy was developed to enhance the oxygen replenishment capacity of CuMn2O4 catalysts by synergically engineering the Cu+ and oxygen vacancies (VO). The surface physicochemical properties of the CuMn2O4 catalysts were regulated by the annealing temperature and solvent, and the effect of two different VO (VO from Cu+-VO−Mn3+ and Mn2+-VO−Mn3+ were denoted as VO(CM) and VO(MM), respectively) on oxygen activation were studied. The results demonstrated that the Cu+ and VO synergically promoted the low-temperature reducibility, adsorbed oxygen species, and the oxygen replenishment of CuMn2O4 catalysts. Especially, the abundant Cu+ cations and VO(CM) greatly promoted the transformation of O2 → O2 − → O−. The prepared CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance (T90 = 208 °C), and the reaction route of toluene oxidation over CuMn2O4-EG-350 was confirmed as follows: toluene-benzyl alcohol-benzoate-maleic anhydride-CO2 and H2O. The Cu+-rich CuMn2O4-EG-350 catalyst with an efficient synthetic strategy is a promising industrial catalyst for toluene elimination.
coredata.dc:title: Synergically engineering Cu+ and oxygen vacancies in CuMn2O4 catalysts for enhanced toluene oxidation performance
